sn54.11:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā icchānaṅgale viharati icchānaṅgalavanasaṇḍe.
sn54.11:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in a forest near Icchānaṅgala.

sn54.11:1.3.eng: “Mendicants, I wish to go on retreat for three months.

sn54.11:1.4.pli: Nāmhi kenaci upasaṅkamitabbo, aññatra ekena piṇḍapātanīhārakenā”ti.
sn54.11:1.4.eng: No-one should approach me, except for the one who brings my almsfood.”

sn54.11:1.5.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paṭissutvā nāssudha koci bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamati, aññatra ekena piṇḍapātanīhārakena.
sn54.11:1.5.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied those mendicants. And no-one approached him, except for the one who brought the almsfood.

sn54.11:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tassa temāsassa accayena paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito bhikkhū āmantesi:
sn54.11:2.1.eng: Then after three months had passed, the Buddha came out of retreat and addressed the mendicants:

sn54.11:2.2.pli: “sace kho, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ puccheyyuṃ:
sn54.11:2.2.eng: “Mendicants, if wanderers who follow another religion were to ask you:

sn54.11:2.3.pli: ‘katamenāvuso, vihārena samaṇo gotamo vassāvāsaṃ bahulaṃ vihāsī’ti, evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, bhikkhave, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ evaṃ byākareyyātha:
sn54.11:2.3.eng: ‘Reverends, what was the ascetic Gotama’s usual meditation during the rainy season residence?’ You should answer them like this.

sn54.11:2.4.pli: ‘ānāpānassatisamādhinā kho, āvuso, bhagavā vassāvāsaṃ bahulaṃ vihāsī’ti.
sn54.11:2.4.eng: ‘Reverends, the ascetic Gotama’s usual meditation during the rainy season residence was immersion due to mindfulness of breathing.’

sn54.11:2.5.pli: Idhāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sato assasāmi, sato passasāmi.
sn54.11:2.5.eng: In this regard: mindful, I breathe in. Mindful, I breathe out.

sn54.11:2.6.pli: Dīghaṃ assasanto ‘dīghaṃ assasāmī’ti pajānāmi, dīghaṃ passasanto ‘dīghaṃ passasāmī’ti pajānāmi;
sn54.11:2.6.eng: Breathing in heavily I know: ‘I’m breathing in heavily.’ Breathing out heavily I know: ‘I’m breathing out heavily.’

sn54.11:2.7.pli: rassaṃ assasanto ‘rassaṃ assasāmī’ti pajānāmi, rassaṃ passasanto ‘rassaṃ passasāmī’ti pajānāmi;
sn54.11:2.7.eng: When breathing in lightly I know: ‘I’m breathing in lightly.’ Breathing out lightly I know: ‘I’m breathing out lightly.’

sn54.11:2.8.eng: I know: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the whole body.’ …

sn54.11:2.9.eng: I know: ‘I’ll breathe in observing letting go.’ I know: ‘I’ll breathe out observing letting go.’

sn54.11:3.1.pli: Yañhi taṃ, bhikkhave, sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
sn54.11:3.1.eng: For if anything should be rightly called

sn54.11:3.2.eng: ‘a noble meditation’, or else ‘a divine meditation’, or else ‘a realized one’s meditation’,

sn54.11:3.3.eng: it’s immersion due to mindfulness of breathing.

sn54.11:3.5.pli: Ye te, bhikkhave, bhikkhū sekhā appattamānasā anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ patthayamānā viharanti tesaṃ ānāpānassatisamādhi bhāvito bahulīkato āsavānaṃ khayāya saṃvattati.
sn54.11:3.5.eng: For those mendicants who are trainees—who haven’t achieved their heart’s desire, but live aspiring to the supreme sanctuary from the yoke—the development and cultivation of immersion due to mindfulness of breathing leads to the ending of defilements.

sn54.11:3.6.pli: Ye ca kho te, bhikkhave, bhikkhū arahanto khīṇāsavā vusitavanto katakaraṇīyā ohitabhārā anuppattasadatthā parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojanā sammadaññāvimuttā, tesaṃ ānāpānassatisamādhi bhāvito bahulīkato diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārāya ceva saṃvattati satisampajaññāya ca.
sn54.11:3.6.eng: For those mendicants who are perfected—who have ended the defilements, completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and are rightly freed through enlightenment—the development and cultivation of immersion due to mindfulness of breathing leads to blissful meditation in this life, and to mindfulness and awareness.

sn54.11:4.1.pli: Yañhi taṃ, bhikkhave, sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
sn54.11:4.1.eng: For if anything should be rightly called

sn54.11:4.2.eng: ‘a noble meditation’, or else ‘a divine meditation’, or else ‘a realized one’s meditation’,

sn54.11:4.3.eng: it’s immersion due to mindfulness of breathing.”

sn54.12:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā lomasakaṃbhiyo sakkesu viharati kapilavatthusmiṃ nigrodhārāme.
sn54.12:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Lomasakaṅgiya was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.

sn54.12:1.2.pli: Atha kho mahānāmo sakko yenāyasmā lomasakaṃbhiyo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ lomasakaṃbhiyaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho mahānāmo sakko āyasmantaṃ lomasakaṃbhiyaṃ etadavoca:
sn54.12:1.2.eng: Then Mahānāma the Sakyan went up to Venerable Lomasakaṅgiya, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

sn54.12:1.3.pli: “so eva nu kho, bhante, sekho vihāro so tathāgatavihāro, udāhu aññova sekho vihāro añño tathāgatavihāro”ti?
sn54.12:1.3.eng: “Sir, is the meditation of a trainee just the same as the meditation of a realized one? Or is the meditation of a trainee different from the meditation of a realized one?”

sn54.12:2.1.pli: “Na kho, āvuso mahānāma, sveva sekho vihāro, so tathāgatavihāro.
sn54.12:2.1.eng: “Reverend Mahānāma, the meditation of a trainee and a realized one are not the same;

sn54.12:2.2.pli: Añño kho, āvuso mahānāma, sekho vihāro, añño tathāgatavihāro.

sn54.12:2.3.pli: Ye te, āvuso mahānāma, bhikkhū sekhā appattamānasā anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ patthayamānā viharanti, te pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya viharanti.
sn54.12:2.3.eng: Those mendicants who are trainees haven’t achieved their heart’s desire, but live aspiring for the supreme sanctuary from the yoke. They meditate after giving up the five hindrances.

sn54.12:2.5.eng: The hindrances of sensual desire, ill will,

sn54.12:3.1.pli: Yepi te, āvuso mahānāma, bhikkhū sekhā appattamānasā anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ patthayamānā viharanti, te ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya viharanti.
sn54.12:3.1.eng: Those who are trainee mendicants … meditate after giving up the five hindrances.

sn54.12:4.1.pli: Ye ca kho te, āvuso mahānāma, bhikkhū arahanto khīṇāsavā vusitavanto katakaraṇīyā ohitabhārā anuppattasadatthā parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojanā sammadaññāvimuttā, tesaṃ pañca nīvaraṇā pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.
sn54.12:4.1.eng: Those mendicants who are perfected—who have ended the defilements, completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and are rightly freed through enlightenment—for them, the five hindrances are cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

sn54.12:4.3.pli: Kāmacchandanīvaraṇaṃ pahīnaṃ ucchinnamūlaṃ tālāvatthukataṃ anabhāvaṅkataṃ āyatiṃ anuppādadhammaṃ;

sn54.12:4.7.pli: vicikicchānīvaraṇaṃ pahīnaṃ ucchinnamūlaṃ tālāvatthukataṃ anabhāvaṅkataṃ āyatiṃ anuppādadhammaṃ.

sn54.12:5.1.pli: Ye te, āvuso mahānāma, bhikkhū arahanto khīṇāsavā vusitavanto katakaraṇīyā ohitabhārā anuppattasadatthā parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojanā sammadaññāvimuttā, tesaṃ ime pañca nīvaraṇā pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.
sn54.12:5.1.eng: Those mendicants who are perfected—who have ended the defilements … for them, the five hindrances are cut off at the root … and unable to arise in the future.

sn54.12:5.2.pli: Tadamināpetaṃ, āvuso mahānāma, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā—
sn54.12:5.2.eng: And here’s another way to understand how

sn54.12:5.3.eng: the meditation of a trainee and a realized one are different.

sn54.12:6.1.pli: Ekamidaṃ, āvuso mahānāma, samayaṃ bhagavā icchānaṅgale viharati icchānaṅgalavanasaṇḍe.
sn54.12:6.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in a forest near Icchānaṅgala.

sn54.12:6.2.pli: Tatra kho, āvuso mahānāma, bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi:

sn54.12:6.3.eng: ‘Mendicants, I wish to go on retreat for three months.

sn54.12:6.4.pli: Nāmhi kenaci upasaṅkamitabbo, aññatra ekena piṇḍapātanīhārakenā’ti.
sn54.12:6.4.eng: No-one should approach me, except for the one who brings my almsfood.’

sn54.12:6.5.pli: ‘Evaṃ, bhante’ti kho, āvuso mahānāma, te bhikkhū bhagavato paṭissutvā nāssudha koci bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamati, aññatra ekena piṇḍapātanīhārakena.
sn54.12:6.5.eng: ‘Yes, sir,’ replied those mendicants. And no-one approached him, except for the one who brought the almsfood.

sn54.12:7.1.pli: Atha kho, āvuso, bhagavā tassa temāsassa accayena paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito bhikkhū āmantesi:
sn54.12:7.1.eng: Then after three months had passed, the Buddha came out of retreat and addressed the mendicants:

sn54.12:7.2.pli: ‘sace kho, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ puccheyyuṃ:
sn54.12:7.2.eng: ‘Mendicants, if wanderers who follow another religion were to ask you:

sn54.12:7.3.pli: “katamenāvuso, vihārena samaṇo gotamo vassāvāsaṃ bahulaṃ vihāsī”ti, evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, bhikkhave, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ evaṃ byākareyyātha:
sn54.12:7.3.eng: “Reverends, what was the ascetic Gotama’s usual meditation during the rainy season residence?” You should answer them like this:

sn54.12:7.4.pli: “ānāpānassatisamādhinā kho, āvuso, bhagavā vassāvāsaṃ bahulaṃ vihāsī”’ti.
sn54.12:7.4.eng: “Reverends, the ascetic Gotama’s usual meditation during the rainy season residence was immersion due to mindfulness of breathing.”

sn54.12:7.5.pli: Idhāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sato assasāmi, sato passasāmi.
sn54.12:7.5.eng: In this regard: mindful, I breathe in. Mindful, I breathe out.

sn54.12:7.6.pli: Dīghaṃ assasanto dīghaṃ assasāmīti pajānāmi, dīghaṃ passasanto dīghaṃ passasāmīti pajānāmi …pe…
sn54.12:7.6.eng: Breathing in heavily I know: “I’m breathing in heavily.” Breathing out heavily I know: “I’m breathing out heavily.” …

sn54.12:7.7.pli: paṭinissaggānupassī assasissāmīti pajānāmi, paṭinissaggānupassī passasissāmīti pajānāmi.
sn54.12:7.7.eng: I know: “I’ll breathe in observing letting go.” I know: “I’ll breathe out observing letting go.”

sn54.12:8.1.pli: Yañhi taṃ, bhikkhave, sammā vadamāno vadeyya—
sn54.12:8.1.eng: For if anything should be rightly called

sn54.12:8.2.pli: ariyavihāro itipi, brahmavihāro itipi, tathāgatavihāro itipi.
sn54.12:8.2.eng: “noble meditation”, or else “divine meditation’, or else “a realized one’s meditation”,

sn54.12:8.3.eng: it’s immersion due to mindfulness of breathing.

sn54.12:8.4.pli: ariyavihāro itipi, brahmavihāro itipi, tathāgatavihāro itipi.

sn54.12:9.1.pli: Ye te, bhikkhave, bhikkhū sekhā appattamānasā anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ patthayamānā viharanti, tesaṃ ānāpānassatisamādhi bhāvito bahulīkato āsavānaṃ khayāya saṃvattati.
sn54.12:9.1.eng: For those mendicants who are trainees—who haven’t achieved their heart’s desire, but live aspiring for the supreme sanctuary from the yoke—the development and cultivation of immersion due to mindfulness of breathing leads to the ending of defilements.

sn54.12:10.1.pli: Ye ca kho te, bhikkhave, bhikkhū arahanto khīṇāsavā vusitavanto katakaraṇīyā ohitabhārā anuppattasadatthā parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojanā sammadaññāvimuttā, tesaṃ ānāpānassatisamādhi bhāvito bahulīkato diṭṭheva dhamme sukhavihārāya ceva saṃvattati satisampajaññāya ca.
sn54.12:10.1.eng: For those mendicants who are perfected—who have ended the defilements, completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and are rightly freed through enlightenment—the development and cultivation of immersion due to mindfulness of breathing leads to blissful meditation in this very life, and to mindfulness and awareness.

sn54.12:11.1.pli: Yañhi taṃ, bhikkhave, sammā vadamāno vadeyya—
sn54.12:11.1.eng: For if anything should be rightly called

sn54.12:11.2.pli: ariyavihāro itipi, brahmavihāro itipi, tathāgatavihāro itipi.
sn54.12:11.2.eng: “noble meditation”, or else “divine meditation’, or else “a realized one’s meditation”,

sn54.12:11.3.eng: it’s immersion due to mindfulness of breathing.’

sn54.12:11.4.pli: ariyavihāro itipi, brahmavihāro itipi, tathāgatavihāro itipīti.

sn54.12:11.5.pli: Iminā kho etaṃ, āvuso mahānāma, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ, yathā—
sn54.12:11.5.eng: This is another way to understand how

sn54.12:11.6.eng: the meditation of a trainee and a realized one are different.”

sn54.13:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn54.13:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn54.13:1.3.pli: “atthi nu kho, bhante, ekadhammo bhāvito bahulīkato cattāro dhamme paripūreti, cattāro dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā satta dhamme paripūrenti, satta dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā dve dhamme paripūrentī”ti?
sn54.13:1.3.eng: “Sir, is there one thing that, when developed and cultivated, fulfills four things; and those four things, when developed and cultivated, fulfill seven things; and those seven things, when developed and cultivated, fulfill two things?”

sn54.13:2.1.pli: “Atthi kho, ānanda, ekadhammo bhāvito bahulīkato cattāro dhamme paripūreti, cattāro dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā satta dhamme paripūrenti, satta dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā dve dhamme paripūrentī”ti.

sn54.13:3.1.pli: “Katamo pana, bhante, ekadhammo bhāvito bahulīkato cattāro dhamme paripūreti, cattāro dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā satta dhamme paripūrenti, satta dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā dve dhamme paripūrentī”ti?

sn54.13:3.2.pli: “Ānāpānassatisamādhi kho, ānanda, ekadhammo bhāvito bahulīkato cattāro satipaṭṭhāne paripūreti, cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvitā bahulīkatā satta bojjhaṅge paripūrenti, satta bojjhaṅgā bhāvitā bahulīkatā vijjāvimuttiṃ paripūrenti.
sn54.13:3.2.eng: “Immersion due to mindfulness of breathing is one thing that, when developed and cultivated, fulfills the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. And the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, when developed and cultivated, fulfill the seven awakening factors. And the seven awakening factors, when developed and cultivated, fulfill knowledge and freedom.

sn54.13:4.1.pli: Kathaṃ bhāvito, ānanda, ānāpānassatisamādhi kathaṃ bahulīkato cattāro satipaṭṭhāne paripūreti?
sn54.13:4.1.eng: And how is mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated so as to fulfill the four kinds of mindfulness meditation?

sn54.13:4.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā nisīdati pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā.
sn54.13:4.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant—gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut—sits down cross-legged, sets their body straight, and establishes mindfulness in their presence.

sn54.13:4.3.eng: Just mindful, they breathe in. Mindful, they breathe out.

sn54.13:4.4.pli: Dīghaṃ vā assasanto ‘dīghaṃ assasāmī’ti pajānāti, dīghaṃ vā passasanto ‘dīghaṃ passasāmī’ti pajānāti …pe…
sn54.13:4.4.eng: Breathing in heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing in heavily.’ Breathing out heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing out heavily.’ …

sn54.13:4.5.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing letting go.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing letting go.’

sn54.13:5.1.pli: Yasmiṃ samaye, ānanda, bhikkhu dīghaṃ vā assasanto ‘dīghaṃ assasāmī’ti pajānāti, dīghaṃ vā passasanto ‘dīghaṃ passasāmī’ti pajānāti;
sn54.13:5.1.eng: There’s a time when a mendicant is breathing in heavily, and they know: ‘I’m breathing in heavily.’ Breathing out heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing out heavily.’

sn54.13:5.3.pli: ‘passambhayaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ assasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘passambhayaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ passasissāmī’ti sikkhati—
sn54.13:5.3.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in stilling the physical process.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out stilling the physical process.’

sn54.13:5.4.pli: kāye kāyānupassī, ānanda, bhikkhu tasmiṃ samaye viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn54.13:5.4.eng: At such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn54.13:5.6.eng: Because the breath is a certain aspect of the body, I say.

sn54.13:5.7.pli: Tasmātihānanda, kāye kāyānupassī bhikkhu tasmiṃ samaye viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn54.13:5.7.eng: Therefore, at such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn54.13:6.1.pli: Yasmiṃ samaye, ānanda, bhikkhu ‘pītippaṭisaṃvedī assasissāmī’ti sikkhati,
sn54.13:6.1.eng: There’s a time when a mendicant practices like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing rapture …

sn54.13:6.4.pli: ‘passambhayaṃ cittasaṅkhāraṃ assasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘passambhayaṃ cittasaṅkhāraṃ passasissāmī’ti sikkhati—
sn54.13:6.4.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in stilling the mental process.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out stilling the mental process.’

sn54.13:6.5.pli: vedanāsu vedanānupassī, ānanda, bhikkhu tasmiṃ samaye viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn54.13:6.5.eng: At such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn54.13:6.7.pli: Vedanāññatarāhaṃ, ānanda, etaṃ vadāmi, yadidaṃ—assāsapassāsānaṃ sādhukaṃ manasikāraṃ.
sn54.13:6.7.eng: Because careful application of mind to the in-breaths and out-breaths is a certain aspect of feelings, I say.

sn54.13:6.8.pli: Tasmātihānanda, vedanāsu vedanānupassī bhikkhu tasmiṃ samaye viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn54.13:6.8.eng: Therefore, at such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn54.13:7.1.pli: Yasmiṃ samaye, ānanda, bhikkhu ‘cittappaṭisaṃvedī assasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘cittappaṭisaṃvedī passasissāmī’ti sikkhati;
sn54.13:7.1.eng: There’s a time when a mendicant practices like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the mind.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the mind.’

sn54.13:7.2.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in gladdening the mind …

sn54.13:7.4.pli: ‘vimocayaṃ cittaṃ assasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘vimocayaṃ cittaṃ passasissāmī’ti sikkhati—
sn54.13:7.4.eng: freeing the mind.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out freeing the mind.’

sn54.13:7.5.pli: citte cittānupassī, ānanda, bhikkhu tasmiṃ samaye viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn54.13:7.5.eng: At such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn54.13:7.7.pli: Nāhaṃ, ānanda, muṭṭhassatissa asampajānassa ānāpānassatisamādhibhāvanaṃ vadāmi.
sn54.13:7.7.eng: Because there is no development of immersion due to mindfulness of breathing for someone who is unmindful and lacks awareness, I say.

sn54.13:7.8.pli: Tasmātihānanda, citte cittānupassī bhikkhu tasmiṃ samaye viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn54.13:7.8.eng: Therefore, at such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn54.13:8.1.eng: There’s a time when a mendicant practices like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing impermanence …

sn54.13:8.4.eng: letting go.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing letting go.’

sn54.13:8.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī, ānanda, bhikkhu tasmiṃ samaye viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn54.13:8.5.eng: At such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn54.13:8.6.pli: So yaṃ taṃ hoti abhijjhādomanassānaṃ pahānaṃ taṃ paññāya disvā sādhukaṃ ajjhupekkhitā hoti.
sn54.13:8.6.eng: Having seen with wisdom the giving up of covetousness and displeasure, they watch closely over with equanimity.

sn54.13:8.7.pli: Tasmātihānanda, dhammesu dhammānupassī bhikkhu tasmiṃ samaye viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn54.13:8.7.eng: Therefore, at such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn54.13:9.1.pli: Evaṃ bhāvito kho, ānanda, ānāpānassatisamādhi evaṃ bahulīkato cattāro satipaṭṭhāne paripūreti.
sn54.13:9.1.eng: That’s how immersion due to mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated so as to fulfill the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn54.13:10.1.pli: Kathaṃ bhāvitā cānanda, cattāro satipaṭṭhānā kathaṃ bahulīkatā satta bojjhaṅge paripūrenti?
sn54.13:10.1.eng: And how are the four kinds of mindfulness meditation developed and cultivated so as to fulfill the seven awakening factors?

sn54.13:10.2.pli: Yasmiṃ samaye, ānanda, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati—
sn54.13:10.2.eng: Whenever a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body,

sn54.13:10.3.pli: upaṭṭhitāssa tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhuno sati hoti asammuṭṭhā.
sn54.13:10.3.eng: their mindfulness is established and lucid.

sn54.13:10.4.pli: Yasmiṃ samaye, ānanda, bhikkhuno upaṭṭhitā sati hoti asammuṭṭhā—satisambojjhaṅgo tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhuno āraddho hoti, satisambojjhaṅgaṃ tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhu bhāveti, satisambojjhaṅgo tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhuno bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchati.
sn54.13:10.4.eng: At such a time, a mendicant has activated the awakening factor of mindfulness; they develop it and perfect it.

sn54.13:11.1.pli: So tathā sato viharanto taṃ dhammaṃ paññāya pavicinati pavicarati parivīmaṃsamāpajjati.
sn54.13:11.1.eng: As they live mindfully in this way they investigate, explore, and inquire into that principle with wisdom.

sn54.13:11.2.pli: Yasmiṃ samaye, ānanda, bhikkhu tathā sato viharanto taṃ dhammaṃ paññāya pavicinati pavicarati parivīmaṃsamāpajjati—
sn54.13:11.2.eng: At such a time, a mendicant has activated the awakening factor of investigation of principles; they develop it and perfect it.

sn54.13:11.3.pli: dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgo tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhuno āraddho hoti, dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgaṃ tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhu bhāveti, dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgo tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhuno bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchati.

sn54.13:12.1.pli: Tassa taṃ dhammaṃ paññāya pavicinato pavicarato parivīmaṃsamāpajjato āraddhaṃ hoti vīriyaṃ asallīnaṃ.
sn54.13:12.1.eng: As they investigate principles with wisdom in this way their energy is roused up and unflagging.

sn54.13:12.2.pli: Yasmiṃ samaye, ānanda, bhikkhuno taṃ dhammaṃ paññāya pavicinato pavicarato parivīmaṃsamāpajjato āraddhaṃ hoti vīriyaṃ asallīnaṃ—
sn54.13:12.2.eng: At such a time, a mendicant has activated the awakening factor of energy; they develop it and perfect it.

sn54.13:12.3.pli: vīriyasambojjhaṅgo tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhuno āraddho hoti, vīriyasambojjhaṅgaṃ tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhu bhāveti, vīriyasambojjhaṅgo tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhuno bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchati.

sn54.13:13.1.eng: When you’re energetic, rapture not of the flesh arises.

sn54.13:13.2.pli: Yasmiṃ samaye, ānanda, bhikkhuno āraddhavīriyassa uppajjati pīti nirāmisā—
sn54.13:13.2.eng: At such a time, a mendicant has activated the awakening factor of rapture; they develop it and perfect it.

sn54.13:13.3.pli: pītisambojjhaṅgo tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhuno āraddho hoti, pītisambojjhaṅgaṃ tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhu bhāveti, pītisambojjhaṅgo tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhuno bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchati.

sn54.13:14.1.eng: When the mind is full of rapture, the body and mind become tranquil.

sn54.13:14.2.pli: Yasmiṃ samaye, ānanda, bhikkhuno pītimanassa kāyopi passambhati, cittampi passambhati—
sn54.13:14.2.eng: At such a time, a mendicant has activated the awakening factor of tranquility; they develop it and perfect it.

sn54.13:14.3.pli: passaddhisambojjhaṅgo tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhuno āraddho hoti, passaddhisambojjhaṅgaṃ tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhu bhāveti, passaddhisambojjhaṅgo tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhuno bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchati.

sn54.13:15.1.eng: When the body is tranquil and one feels bliss, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.

sn54.13:15.2.pli: Yasmiṃ samaye, ānanda, bhikkhuno passaddhakāyassa sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati—
sn54.13:15.2.eng: At such a time, a mendicant has activated the awakening factor of immersion; they develop it and perfect it.

sn54.13:15.3.pli: samādhisambojjhaṅgo tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhuno āraddho hoti, samādhisambojjhaṅgaṃ tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhu bhāveti, samādhisambojjhaṅgo tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhuno bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchati.

sn54.13:16.1.pli: So tathāsamāhitaṃ cittaṃ sādhukaṃ ajjhupekkhitā hoti.
sn54.13:16.1.eng: They closely watch over that mind immersed in samādhi.

sn54.13:16.2.pli: Yasmiṃ samaye, ānanda, bhikkhu tathāsamāhitaṃ cittaṃ sādhukaṃ ajjhupekkhitā hoti—
sn54.13:16.2.eng: At such a time, a mendicant has activated the awakening factor of equanimity; they develop it and perfect it.

sn54.13:16.3.pli: upekkhāsambojjhaṅgo tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhuno āraddho hoti, upekkhāsambojjhaṅgaṃ tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhu bhāveti, upekkhāsambojjhaṅgo tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhuno bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchati.

sn54.13:17.1.eng: Whenever a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of feelings …

sn54.13:17.4.pli: upaṭṭhitāssa tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhuno sati hoti asammuṭṭhā.
sn54.13:17.4.eng: their mindfulness is established and lucid.

sn54.13:17.5.pli: Yasmiṃ samaye, ānanda, bhikkhuno upaṭṭhitā sati hoti asammuṭṭhā—
sn54.13:17.5.eng: At such a time, a mendicant has activated the awakening factor of mindfulness; they develop it and perfect it. …

sn54.13:17.6.pli: satisambojjhaṅgo tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhuno āraddho hoti, satisambojjhaṅgaṃ tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhu bhāveti, satisambojjhaṅgo tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhuno bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchati.

sn54.13:17.7.eng: (Tell in full as for the first kind of mindfulness meditation.)

sn54.13:18.1.pli: So tathāsamāhitaṃ cittaṃ sādhukaṃ ajjhupekkhitā hoti.
sn54.13:18.1.eng: They closely watch over that mind immersed in samādhi.

sn54.13:18.2.pli: Yasmiṃ samaye, ānanda, bhikkhu tathāsamāhitaṃ cittaṃ sādhukaṃ ajjhupekkhitā hoti—
sn54.13:18.2.eng: At such a time, a mendicant has activated the awakening factor of equanimity; they develop it and perfect it.

sn54.13:18.3.pli: upekkhāsambojjhaṅgo tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhuno āraddho hoti, upekkhāsambojjhaṅgaṃ tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhu bhāveti, upekkhāsambojjhaṅgo tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhuno bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchati.

sn54.13:18.4.pli: Evaṃ bhāvitā kho, ānanda, cattāro satipaṭṭhānā evaṃ bahulīkatā satta bojjhaṅge paripūrenti.
sn54.13:18.4.eng: That’s how the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are developed and cultivated so as to fulfill the seven awakening factors.

sn54.13:19.1.pli: Kathaṃ bhāvitā, ānanda, satta bojjhaṅgā kathaṃ bahulīkatā vijjāvimuttiṃ paripūrenti?
sn54.13:19.1.eng: And how are the seven awakening factors developed and cultivated so as to fulfill knowledge and freedom?

sn54.13:19.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu satisambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ,
sn54.13:19.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops the awakening factors of mindfulness,

sn54.13:19.3.eng: investigation of principles, energy, rapture, tranquility, immersion,

sn54.13:19.4.pli: upekkhāsambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ.
sn54.13:19.4.eng: and equanimity, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.

sn54.13:19.5.pli: Evaṃ bhāvitā kho, ānanda, satta bojjhaṅgā evaṃ bahulīkatā vijjāvimuttiṃ paripūrentī”ti.
sn54.13:19.5.eng: That’s how the seven awakening factors are developed and cultivated so as to fulfill knowledge and freedom.”

sn54.14:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn54.14:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:

sn54.14:1.2.pli: “atthi nu kho, ānanda, ekadhammo bhāvito bahulīkato cattāro dhamme paripūreti, cattāro dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā satta dhamme paripūrenti, satta dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā dve dhamme paripūrentī”ti.
sn54.14:1.2.eng: “Ānanda, is there one thing that, when developed and cultivated, fulfills four things; and those four things, when developed and cultivated, fulfill seven things; and those seven things, when developed and cultivated, fulfill two things?”

sn54.14:1.3.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn54.14:1.4.pli: “atthānanda, ekadhammo bhāvito bahulīkato cattāro dhamme paripūreti, cattāro dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā satta dhamme paripūrenti, satta dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā dve dhamme paripūrenti.

sn54.14:2.1.pli: Katamo cānanda, ekadhammo bhāvito bahulīkato cattāro dhamme paripūreti, cattāro dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā satta dhamme paripūrenti, satta dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā dve dhamme paripūrenti?
sn54.14:2.1.eng: And what is that one thing?

sn54.14:2.2.pli: Ānāpānassatisamādhi, ānanda, ekadhammo bhāvito bahulīkato cattāro satipaṭṭhāne paripūreti, cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvitā bahulīkatā satta bojjhaṅge paripūrenti, satta bojjhaṅgā bhāvitā bahulīkatā vijjāvimuttiṃ paripūrentīti.
sn54.14:2.2.eng: Immersion due to mindfulness of breathing is one thing that, when developed and cultivated, fulfills the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. And the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, when developed and cultivated, fulfill the seven awakening factors. And the seven awakening factors, when developed and cultivated, fulfill knowledge and freedom.

sn54.14:2.3.pli: Kathaṃ bhāvito cānanda, ānāpānassatisamādhi, kathaṃ bahulīkato cattāro satipaṭṭhāne paripūreti?
sn54.14:2.3.eng: And how is mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated so as to fulfill the four kinds of mindfulness meditation? …

sn54.14:2.5.pli: evaṃ bhāvitā kho, ānanda, satta bojjhaṅgā evaṃ bahulīkatā vijjāvimuttiṃ paripūrentī”ti.
sn54.14:2.5.eng: That’s how the seven awakening factors are developed and cultivated so as to fulfill knowledge and freedom.”

sn54.15:1.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn54.15:1.1.eng: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn54.15:1.2.pli: “atthi nu kho, bhante, ekadhammo bhāvito bahulīkato cattāro dhamme paripūreti, cattāro dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā satta dhamme paripūrenti, satta dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā dve dhamme paripūrentī”ti?
sn54.15:1.2.eng: “Sir, is there one thing that, when developed and cultivated, fulfills four things; and those four things, when developed and cultivated, fulfill seven things; and those seven things, when developed and cultivated, fulfill two things?”

sn54.15:1.3.pli: “Atthi kho, bhikkhave, ekadhammo bhāvito bahulīkato cattāro dhamme paripūreti, cattāro dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā satta dhamme paripūrenti, satta dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā dve dhamme paripūrentī”ti.

sn54.15:2.1.pli: “Katamo pana, bhante, ekadhammo bhāvito bahulīkato cattāro dhamme paripūreti, cattāro dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā satta dhamme paripūrenti, satta dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā dve dhamme paripūrentī”ti?

sn54.15:2.2.pli: “Ānāpānassatisamādhi kho, bhikkhave, ekadhammo bhāvito bahulīkato cattāro satipaṭṭhāne paripūreti, cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvitā bahulīkatā satta bojjhaṅge paripūrenti, satta bojjhaṅgā bhāvitā bahulīkatā vijjāvimuttiṃ paripūrentīti.
sn54.15:2.2.eng: “Immersion due to mindfulness of breathing is one thing that, when developed and cultivated, fulfills the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. And the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, when developed and cultivated, fulfill the seven awakening factors. And the seven awakening factors, when developed and cultivated, fulfill knowledge and freedom.

sn54.15:3.1.pli: Kathaṃ bhāvito ca, bhikkhave, ānāpānassatisamādhi kathaṃ bahulīkato cattāro satipaṭṭhāne paripūreti?
sn54.15:3.1.eng: And how is mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated so as to fulfill the four kinds of mindfulness meditation? …

sn54.15:3.3.pli: evaṃ bhāvitā kho, bhikkhave, satta bojjhaṅgā evaṃ bahulīkatā vijjāvimuttiṃ paripūrentī”ti.
sn54.15:3.3.eng: That’s how the seven awakening factors are developed and cultivated so as to fulfill knowledge and freedom.”
